---

## What is a Terminal?

Terminal (also known as _command lines_ or _consoles_) is a tool that
allows us to use our computer in a text-based format by running a program we call [<u>**a shell**</u>](#what-is-a-shell).

Instead of having a _GUI_ that you can interact with (buttons to click, animations to interact with, etc), in the terminal:

- You will interact with computer by typing in commands (text)
- Your computer will display most output through text too!

> A **GUI** (_Graphical User Interface_) is a tool that you are using most of the time to interact with your computer. It uses icons, menus, combinations of mouse and keyboard input, etc, to let you interact with your computer.

---

## What is a Shell?

Shell is a program that processes commands you input into the terminal and outputs the result. It allows you (the user) to interact with your operating system (often referred as the _Kernel_).

> There are different types of shell available. We are going to learn the default shell in MacOS: Z Shell (ZSH).

> ZSH is very similar to another shell called Bash and all commands that we will learn can be used in both types of shell without any difference.

---

## Computer Layer

This is how a Shell interacts with your computer:
![Computer Layer](https://snipcademy.com/img/articles/linux-command-line-environment/01-shells.svg)

Alternative picture:

![Computer Layer 2](data:image/png;base64,)

Your computer is made of layers of programs!
Your opearting system (Kernel) is the deepest layer of software that acts as a bridge between the applications in your computer and your computer hardware (CPU).

---

## Starting a Terminal

To open your terminal:

1. Type `Cmd + Space`. This should open a Spotlight Search in your computer.
2. Type in `Terminal` and click the first application that pops up.
3. When your Terminal opens, you should see an image like the following:
   ![Terminal Home](/img/Terminal.png)

4. You can start typing commands into your terminal. Some of the basic commands will be explained [here](</Terminal%20Commands%20(Basic).MD>).

---

## MacOS File System

In MacOS, your file system will look roughly as follow:
![MacOS File System](data:image/png;base64,)

You can think of the image above as an inverted tree.

The very top of the tree is what we call a "root of the tree". At the very top of the tree, there's a folder/directory that contains all of the files and folders in your program. This directory is called the <u>**Root Directory**</u>.

---

## Terminal Default Directory

Take a look at the image below:
![Home Directory](/img/FileTree.gif)

When open a Terminal, by default, it's going to open the folder that contains all the files under your username (_red circled in the image above_).

Your username directory is often referred as the <u>**Home Directory**</u> and often abbreviated with the `~` (_tilde_) sign.

---

## Terminal Layout

Take a look at the image below:
![Terminal Layout](/img/Terminal%20Layout.png)

1. The Red arrow above is pointing to the `~` (_tilde_) sign.

   By default, your Terminal is pointing to the <u>**Home Directory**</u> which is abbreviated with the `~` (_tilde_) sign.

2. The Green arrow above is pointing to the `$` (_dollar_) sign.

   The `$` (_dollar_) sign indicates the starting point where you can type in the commands you want to execute.
